narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: fascinating class that really benefited from the multiple anthropological viewpoints of the professors. I gained an overview of war from both a "deep time" view and also insights into how modern warfare impacts all portions of the population.

I learned to look at abstract social concepts in a rigorous way and to find questions within arguments and theories with regard to these concepts. I gained new perspectives on war in ways that taught me to consider contemporary conflicts -- and media representations of them -- in a critical fashion.

Strong foundations in Biological Anthropoloty, Archaeology, and Sociocultural Anthropology. We also learned about warfare throughout history and prehistory across the world.  Utterly fascinating course!

How to think and read about war from an anthropological perspective. Class is very broad and largely focused on thematic concepts and intersections between biological, archeological and socio-cultural anthropology as these areas relate to war and conflict.

I feel like I gained a better understanding of archaeological and anthropological methods for looking at past and present warfare. I learned how to think about and begin to ask questions about big topics such as genocide, ritual warfare, and total warfare.
Insights into how war is viewed and thought of in different cultures, the history of war, and the cultural impacts of it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a well thought-out, cotaught class that really tackled many aspects of a difficult subject.

This course was led my some really great professors and TFs, and it synthesized a lot of different types of information in really cool ways. Lectures were interesting and the class was generally low-stress, and it encouraged me to ask questions I'd never considered before. One way it could improve is by ending more consistently on time.

This course was excellent in terms of the range of topics it covered and how it thematically related those to war. However, in a lot of ways this class felt like taking three different classes simultaneously - one focused on archeology, the other two focused on biological and socio-cultural anthropology, respectively - since a lot of the assignments allowed students to choose their own topics, I could see how a student who just prefers archeological studies could have had a wildly different experience than a student who just prefers to study biological anthropology. I wish the course did more to integrate the three perspectives in each case study that we looked at, instead of using case studies as independent examples of each area. For instance, when talking about genocide in Rwanda - we could have learned about socio-cultural perspectives of genocide and post-atrocity reconciliation, but also considered how forensic archeology related to the process of reconciliation.

Strengths: very cool to be taught by all 3 professors, professors all very engaged and willing to connect with students both in and out of class, readings very interesting
Weaknesses: sometimes lectures were unstructured which made it difficult to follow

Strength: A variety of perspectives, the three professors all bring their own specialty and a lot of students taking a class are very open to sharing their own experiences;

Weakness: Sometimes it could feel a little bit disorganized, given the structure of the course, and at points it felt a little unsatisfying because there isn't really an "answer" to the big questions being posed
I enjoyed how interactive it was.

Unfortunately, I did not find the material as engaging as I had hoped it would be, which was, in part, the result of assigning too much reading. At the beginning of the semester, this was not as big of an issue, but especially towards the end, 100+ pages could be assigned for one class. This was particularly frustrating as we never talked about all of it, but we were not told to prioritize some readings over others, and this left me not motivated to do any of the reading because the chances were slim that I'd do the "right" one for what we were talking about. The discussion posts did require that you at least do some of the readings, but I felt like I was largely skating by and not getting as much out of the class as I would've if less reading has been assigned because then I would've actually done it all. Instead, I was constantly fearful of speaking because I didn't want to say something that would expose me for not having done all the reading. Additionally, I didn't appreciate the comments on our essays when they were to the effect of "I wish you had talked more about xyz" because that's not really helpful feedback for a 2-page paper; I didn't have the space to talk about it more. This probably sounds more negative than I mean it to, but it is something I would like to see improved in the future/is something one should take into account when considering this course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the group project -- it helped me connect with my peers when I wouldn't have otherwise!

This class was very engaging, although the size of the lecture was not as facilitating to open discussion as the professors probably hoped. This could have been supplemented by discussion sections but my particular section was set up in a way where we had little open discussion - instead just rehashing the readings and answering particular questions about the readings and lectures from students.
Zoom discussion section was beneficial to discuss and connect with other students, breakout rooms in lecture were helpful as well.

The discussion sections encouraged participation, and students were asked to post their 'reflection response' on the week's reading on Canvas discussion forum; though the lectures did not have as much engagement (especially dependent on the Prof. who was lecturing) and generally did not have participation from everyone in the class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a great course to think about war in a totally different way, and the assignments were creative and low-stress. I'd recommend this course to someone coming from any department!
I strongly recommend this course! It is very interesting.  There is a lot of reading but the class is top-tier!

Yes. This course is rare in the sense that it's fun while also very informative and engaging over the material. It's also uncommon for three professors of different areas within anthropology to co-teach a course, which is a great experience - especially if you're new to the anthropology department (like an underclassman) and want to get a feel for what sub-fields you might be interested in.
Yes definitely if you want to learn about anthropology and archaeology and are at all interested in the history and practice of war.

I think it is a really nice anthropology course (and So credit) for anyone who is: 1) generally interested in finding out more about anthropology, no previous experience necessary; 2) want to engage with a body of material from at least three different perspectives and ready to critically engage with them through discussions both written and oral; 3) interested in understanding warfare, genocide, peace-building (could be out of academic, but also completely valid if out of personal interest/background/experience); but it is not a history course and not a rigorous course on methodology in the field
Yes, if they are interested in war.

I want to be able to recommend this course, and I want to like it more than I did, but unfortunately, I had some issues that were hard to get past. The main one being that too much reading was assigned, leaving me less engaged with the material than I would've been had there been fewer, more targeted readings. At the beginning of the semester, this was not as big of an issue, but especially towards the end, 100+ pages could be assigned for one class. This was particularly frustrating as we never talked about all of it, but we were not told to prioritize some readings over others, and this left me not motivated to do any of the reading because the chances were slim that I'd do the "right" one for what we were talking about. The discussion posts did require that you at least do some of the readings, but I felt like I was largely skating by and not getting as much out of the class as I would've if less reading has been assigned because then I would've actually done it all. Instead, I was constantly fearful of speaking because I didn't want to say something that would expose me for not having done all the reading. Additionally, I didn't appreciate the comments on our essays when they were to the effect of "I wish you had talked more about xyz" because that's not really helpful feedback for a 2-page paper; I didn't have the space to talk about it more. This probably sounds more negative than I mean it to, but it is something I would like to see improved in the future/is something one should take into account when considering this course, making it hard for me to say whether or not I recommend it.
